title.narrative: Cross-Border Dialogue for Peace in the Great Lakes region, phase II
Gränsöverskridande dialog för fred i Stora Sjö-regionen, fas II

description.narrative:
Organisationen Interpeace har ansökt till ambassaden om finansiering för insatsen "Cross-Border Dialogue for Peace in the Great Lakes Region, phase II", under perioden 1 januari 2017 - 31 december 2020.
Denna insats är en fortsättning av det framgångsrika projektet "Trans-Border Dialogue for Peace in the Great Lakes Region" (hädanefter "första fasen", insatsnr 51160058), vilket implementerades av Interpeace och dess samarbetspartners mellan 1 september 2013 - 31 december 2016.
Insatsens kommer att bygga på resultaten i första fasen och den infrastruktur för fred i Stora Sjö-regionen man satt upp i Rwanda, Burundi och Demokratiska Republiken Kongo (DRK). Dess övergripande syfte är att bidra till fred, stabilitet och social sammanhållning i Stora Sjö-regionen genom stärkt motståndskraftskapacitet för fred och försoning samt genom inkluderande och lyhörd samhällsstyrning. För att uppnå detta mål kommer Interpeace och dess sex partnerorganisationer att engagera samhällsmedlemmar och beslutsfattare i syfte att ge plats för inkluderande dialog mellan olika aktörer i regionen; att bedriva forskning som katalyserar debatt och påverkar politik; att främja en regional strategi för fredsutbildning; samt att integrera fredsbyggande metoder i insatser som syftar till att främja ungdomars entrepenörskap.
Insatsens föreslagna budget är ca 83 000 000 SEK, vilken kommer att samfinansieras tillsammans med Schweiz. Ambassadens bidrag uppgår till 40 miljoner SEK.

The international non-governmental organisation Interpeace has applied for a grant from the Embassy of Sweden in Rwanda, for the intervention "Cross-Border Dialogue for Peace in the Great Lakes Region, phase II", during the period 1 January 2017 - 31 December 2020.
This intervention is a continuation of the successful project "Trans-Border Dialogue for Peace in the Great Lakes Region" (hereinafter the "first phase", contribution no 51160058), which was implemented by Interpeace and its partners between 1 September 2013 - 31 December 2016.
The intervention will build on the results from the first phase and the infrastructure for peace in the Great Lakes region that has been set up in Rwanda, Burundi and the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Its overall aim is to contribute to peace, stability and social cohesion through strengthened resilience capacities for peace and reconciliation, cooperation as well as through inclusive and responsive governance. To achieve this goal, Interpeace and its six partner organisations will engage community members and decision makers to provide spaces for inclusive dialogue between diverse actors in the region, to conduct research that catalyses debate and influences policy, to promote a regional approach to peace education and to integrate peacebuilding approaches into efforts to promote youth entrepreneurship.
The intervention's total budget is approx. 83 000 000 SEK, which will be co-financed together with the Swiss Development Cooperation. The Swedish contribution will be 40 million SEK.

The vision for this intervention is a Great Lakes region where there is peace, stability and social cohesion through inclusive and responsive governance and development built upon strengthened resilience capacities for reconciliation and cooperation. In order to reach this vision, the intervention has two intended outcomes:1. Community members of diverse backgrounds, including women and youth, use dialogue to identify their capacities, gaps for peace, reconciliation and development within and across borders; to deconstruct negative stereotypes in order to have mutual positive and collaborative relations; and to come to consensus on peacebuilding and development priorities. They collaborate with CSOs and decision makers to develop and implement solutions to address local and cross-border priorities for peace reconciliation and development. They take independent initiative to build resilience capacities and to drive peace, reconciliation and development within and across their communities; and2. Decision-makers work in partnership with citizens and CSOs to understand the needs, priorities and capacities of the population and to develop solutions (policies and programmes) that address the needs and priorities of the population within and across borders. They partner with citizens and CSOs and collaborate across borders to strengthen citizens’ capacities, to address the needs and priorities of the population, and to advance peace, reconciliation and development across the Great Lakes region.The Embassy assesses that these two intended outcomes are clear and realistic and possible to monitor during the intervention.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution
